snippet: Microscopic spheres of reflective silica in the inner lip of the disco clam help it create its mirror-ball effect underwater. Why the clam does this is still a mystery.
abstract: Lindsey Dougherty study in The Journal of the Royal Society Interface explains mechanism that causes ctenoides ales, commonly known as disco clam, to flash light; clam carries light-reflecting silica inside its lip.
lead_paragraph: Microscopic spheres of reflective silica in the inner lip of the disco clam help it create its mirror-ball effect underwater. Why the clam does this is still a mystery.
